title: The Project MinE data browser: bringing whole-genome sequencing data in ALS to researchers and the public

author: Rick A. A. van der Spek, University Medical Center Utrecht, Utrecht University

segmentation: Good day everybody.
And I know in between you and coffee, but I have very cool tool to show you which is freely available for all of you.
So I hope we can.
I can entertain you for the next couple of minutes.
My name is James pic.
I'm a PhD student in the group of Young.
Belding can learn from there in the Netherlands and first of all I'd like to thank the organizing Committee for the opportunity to present the beta version of our data browser here.
On behalf of the project, mine LS sequencing consortium.
So as we've already heard.
In the last couple of decades, we've learned a lot about LS Genetics.
We know some variants that are involved.
We can explain part of the genetic etiology.
But the remainder of the genetic etiology in LS will probably be in the low frequency to rare frequency variance, as we've learned in the last couple of years.
Because of this, we need very large sample sizes in order to find new associations to the disease.
There.
Four, we need global collaboration in order to get these sample sizes, and Furthermore, as you will know, LS very complex disease, so we need expertise globally in order to solve this disease.
And that's where project mine comes in.
So project Mine is a large international consortium which is largely crowdfunded and at the moment there are 17 countries involved in a in project mine.
With the ultimate aim of whole genome sequencing 22 and a half thousand cases and controls, of which 15,000 RLS case is 7 and a half thousand are controls.
We also aim to include external datasets like top met for example.
At the moment we.
I have about 6 1/2 thousand genomes that have been whole genome sequence and QC.
There are approximately 4000 samples in the pipeline, but these have not yet been Q seat.
And there's six and a half thousand genomes are the genomes that are behind the data browser that I'll show you in a minute.

Within Project Mind we have several working groups, so for example, burden testing, phenotyping, epigenetics etc to perform various analysis within project mind based on the data that we've collected.
So we don't only share data and expertise within the consortium.
We also aim to share data and results and expertise with the whole world.
And that's where the data browser comes in.
The data browser is simply an interface in order to facilitate sharing of data and of results.
With any research initiative in the world.
Furthermore, and the data that's on the data browser itself is group level data.
But we also aim to share the individual level data.
Using the browser, we can we have a platform for which you can with which you can request the data.
And last but not least.
We aim to integrate the project mind data browser with various publicly available datasets, for instance, GTX for gene expression data in order to both facilitate researchers and clinicians.
So there are various components on the website and here I'd like to acknowledge both Sarah Bulletin boards Middelkoop for working on the QC of the data.
And of course setting up the server for the data browser and briefly like to elaborate.
On these components, so we have depth of coverage data for the whole genome sequence.
Yeah.
And this component contains all the data.
Then we have burden testing, so for now it's based on the Dutch data set only.
But this is a beta release and later this year will have the heart release and we aim to have 6 1/2 thousand genomes in the burden.
Testing at that time.
The same goes for the variant table.
It's based on Tooth 2000 genomes for now, but again at the end of the year, we aim to have 6 1/2 thousand cases and controls in that component as well.
And the data you can request is array based data.
This is the 36,000 cases and controls that have been used for the latest.
She was in a less.
So we have this.
Preview of the data browser.
So this is the home page.
What you have is very simple search bar.
You can enter your G name, Gino sambal ID or transcript ID.
You can download the summary statistics for the G was right from the homepage and please read the data sharing policy if you do.
If you're interested in future releases of the data browser, then you can simply enter your email address and will keep you updated once the data behind the data browser has been updated.
So what you can now do is simply enter your favorite gene.
Hit enter.
An if you enter gene name, then by default you'll be carried to the Canonical transcript of that gene.
And in the first component you see transcript details.
We have some basic information regarding on which chromosome it is, how many exons it contains etc.
And then we moved to the second component.
This is the depth depth of coverage we have within the whole genome sequences.
And you see a nice uniform distribution with on the Y axis.
The average depth of coverage, and by default it shows exons only.
But you can simply check the box is an show the introns as well or compared to exact.
As you can see.
We then move on to the next component, which is burden testing.
Then in the lower right corner you see the various aggregation tests of the various burden tests we have SKT T1T5 variable threshold and Mattson Browning.

Then if you look at the figure itself again, the orange components are the axons within this transcript, and then the triangles on top are the variants that have been found that are unique to cases which are the red triangles or predominantly present in cases.
And if you hover over the variance and then you can see some additional information like how many times it was observed in cases and controls, either homozygous or heterozygotes.
Now, if you want to have some more.
Theoretical background about these aggregation tests.
Then you can simply click the burn test info an for all the burn tests that are on the website.
You can see a simple explanation on how it was performed and what it basically means.
So we've integrated the data browser with gene expression data from GTX.
And here you see on the X axis you see the various tissues and on the Y axis the expression levels.
And you can simply subset by gender or by age range if you're interested in that.
And if you want more information regarding the gene expression, you can simply click the GTX portal icon and you'll be carried to the GTX page for this particular gene.
Now we move on to the variant table.
So by default it shows exonic variants with the high or moderate predicted impact only.
But you can create any subset that you'd like.

We also have a few quick subsets like missions only or loss of function variants only, and if you need a bit more information about what variants are contained in these in these exonic regions or internal regions, simply click the region info button or the impact info button and you'll see a small popup screen with some additional information regarding that.
And of course you can download all the variant information in a tab delimited file.

So then in the variant table itself you see some basic information really regarding the variance that we've observed an at the end of the row you see small var, some icon which carries you to the Var's home page.
For additional information on this particular variant.
We also have minor allele frequency of course both for all countries combined, but also stratified per country.
Anne Anne yeah.
Well that was about the information with respect to the transcript based pages.

But if you're interested in what are the most significant burden tests in the entire website, then you don't want to click through 20,000 genes, so we've also included a results page where the working groups within project mine can publish their results if they want prior to publication in a scientific Journal, and we also have overviews of, for example, the burden testing.
So here you see an overview where you can simply say OK, I'm interested in the T1 test.
Show me the most significant.
Jeans that have been found using the T1 test or one of the other burden tests.
You can also search all genes again simply by typing in your favorite gene and looking at the results right there.
This results based rules will be used for additional analysis in the future, of course.
So then you can request individual level data from the website.
Simply enter your name, email address and Institute.
Choose the datasets that you'd like to view some additional information, like the platform on which it was genotyped.

Enter a research question analytic plan, and once you've submitted the request, then the eyes that own the data will get a notification and once you have approval then we can arrange for the data transfer.
So this is how the data browser looks now.
I also wanted to.
Give you a small sneak peek into what's going to be contained in the next release of the data browser.

So we've been working on survival analysis per gene and what you can see here is a Cox proportional hazards model with covariates like a LSF slope diagnostic, deley, aged onset, forced vital capacity, FTD cited onset.
And the two lines represent.
Individual cases that have either no loss of function variants or one or more loss of function variants within that particular gene.
You can also choose whether you want to view misses plus loss of function or loss of function variants only, and then again you can view your.
Your gene of interest on the transcript specific pages or view all survival results in the results page.
Furthermore, we are going to work towards a life release of the data browser and at the time of the live release we aim to have 6 1/2 thousand genomes in all components.
Both cases and controls include the survival analysis that I spoke about.
And integrate with additional databases.
So for example that in human brain Atlas and last but not least, once we have the live release then the source code for the data browser will be online for you to be with.
Said I'd like to acknowledge the large group that has been involved in.
Making this data browser possible and of course my promoters Youngfield Inc and they are not from the back and have one additional.
Notion that's please join our team.
We're looking for postdoc with some whole genome sequencing experience, so if you're interested, please let me know.
